tasks: Conduct a solo user research exercise: Ask yourself 5 questions about your own UX workflow and document your answers using the Zeigarnik Effect framework. (9% score gap reference)
Write a 2-page reflection on your collaboration and communication skills, highlighting areas for improvement and strategies for growth. (0% score gap reference)
Create a video showcasing your design process for a hypothetical project, highlighting your ability to communicate design decisions effectively. (0% score gap reference)
Create a showcase of 3 successful UX design projects that demonstrate your ability to apply the Laws of UX in real-world contexts. (7% score gap reference)

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, your role is to uncover the hidden patterns and behaviors of users, but it starts with building a strong foundation in UX Fundamentals. Focus on developing a solid understanding of user research methods, usability principles, and design thinking to unlock your full potential and take your skills from 7/100 to 90/100.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Usability Heuristics for UI Design
topics.summary: Applying usability heuristics will help Explorer designers identify and address common UX pitfalls, leading to more effective design decisions.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing products using the 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design and document areas for improvement
Create a comprehensive list of potential heuristics violations in a hypothetical product and propose solutions
Design 2 new interfaces that incorporate at least 5 usability heuristics, with clear explanations for design choices

topics.name: Law of Proximity and Visual Design Principles
topics.summary: Mastering the Law of Proximity will help Explorer designers create more intuitive and visually appealing interfaces.
practice_points: Create 5 wireframes with varying levels of proximity (e.g., adjacent, near, far) to demonstrate its impact on user experience
Design a color palette that adheres to the Law of Proximity, including a minimum of 3 distinct colors and their corresponding usage guidelines

topics.name: Conducting Effective User Interviews for UX Research
topics.summary: Developing strong user interview skills will enable Explorer designers to gather valuable insights from users, informing design decisions.
practice_points: Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document findings in a clear, concise report
Create a comprehensive guide for conducting user interviews, including tips for active listening and note-taking

insights.brief: Current score indicates a need for improvement in understanding user needs and behaviors.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not be adequately considering user-centered design principles, such as user research, usability testing, and accessibility. This could lead to a product that is frustrating or unintuitive for users.
actionable: Conduct user interviews and surveys to gain a deeper understanding of user needs and pain points
Review existing user research and validate findings through usability testing
Study industry benchmarks and best practices in UX design

insights.brief: Current score highlights the need for improvement in visual design skills.
insights.detailed: The low score indicates that the designer may not have a strong foundation in visual design principles, such as color theory, typography, and composition. This could result in a product with poor visual appeal or user experience.
actionable: Take online courses or attend workshops to improve visual design skills
Study the work of other designers and analyze what makes their designs effective
Join design communities or forums to stay up-to-date on industry trends

insights.brief: Current score suggests a strong foundation in user research methods.
insights.detailed: The high score indicates that the designer is well-versed in user research techniques, such as user interviews and usability testing. However, it's essential to continue refining these skills to ensure that research is conducted effectively and efficiently.
actionable: Attend user research workshops or conferences to stay current on best practices
Participate in online communities or forums focused on user research
Collaborate with other designers or researchers to gain new insights

insights.brief: Current score indicates a need for improvement in understanding product strategy.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not be adequately considering product goals, target audience, and market trends. This could result in a product that is unclear or unappealing to users.
actionable: Read industry publications or blogs focused on product strategy
Take online courses or attend workshops on product thinking and strategy
Join product-focused communities or forums to stay informed

insights.brief: Current score highlights the need for improvement in collaboration and communication skills.
insights.detailed: The low score indicates that the designer may struggle with effective communication, teamwork, and stakeholder management. This could lead to misunderstandings, missed deadlines, or poor product quality.
actionable: Take courses or attend workshops on collaboration and communication
Join professional organizations or networking groups focused on design and product development
Practice active listening and clear communication with team members and stakeholders
